comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: Hi - found this link to an unnamed newspaper article: www.cairogang.com/other-people/british/castle-intelligenc... The caption under the clipping says Nov 20, but I think the actual clipping says Nov 29. I know nothing about the site the link is on. Also, the NY times has a report for Nov 29 about the raid. Link is here: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10617FB3D5810738... This leads to a PDF doc, and the Bank reference it towards the end... All of this would seem to date the raid to November 28, 1920. Cheers!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/65361386@N05] Thanks for all of this! I'm just wondering if the blowing of the safe, even with 2 explosions, could account for all of the damage evident in the photo. What do you think?

Our metadata says that the above photo was taken "after shelling" - would love to hear from anyone who knows of any heavy fighting/shelling in the Harcourt Street area...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content:
Given the description (in the first link) of the 2 explosions, they seem to have been hurried affairs! I'd be happy to think that all the glass damage was caused from within. Also, I'm not convinced that the middle windows are actually damaged? Could that just be odd reflections on the glass? 
Plus, the outside of the building doesn't look like it's suffered any shell damage - if there were shells, they hardly went cleanly through the windows! Finally, I'm not an expert on the War of Independence (1916 is more my area), but I don't think there were any shelling 'incidents' around that time (wide open to correction here...). Interestingly though, I see the pic was taken by Keogh Bros, a local company, so surely they'd know what they were reporting on? 

All in all, though, I blame the safe-blowing... (Finally, I'd guess that the safe was on the top floor - the only floor with all the blinds pulled. Maybe the soldiers pulled them to 'cover' the blasts?)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65361386@N05] I grant you the explosions might account for the broken windows rather than shelling. And there is suspiciously little structural damage to brickwork. However, the middle windows are sash windows, and you can see the timber framework on the left and middle (middle) windows, but the one on the right (with "Business as usual" sign) has  no timber showing. That window has been completely blown out, or blown in...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: Hmm - I see what you mean about the blown in/out sash window, and I guess that could be corrugated metal in the fanlight, which may also have been broken. By the way, have you seen this photo of the same event: irishvolunteers.org/irish-volunteers-photo-gallery/sinn-f... (I know nothing about the site this pic is on.) It clearly shows that both ground floor windows were smashed as well...
